EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This material supersedes IRM 5.14.9, dated December 18,
Installment Agreement User Fees: Authority and General Information
Routine and Manually Monitored Installment Agreement Dispositions, Independent Review and Appeals 5.14.9
) This IRM describes the installment agreement process. Speciﬁcally, IRM

: a. Describes routine and manually monitored installment agreement tions. b. Discusses considerations with respect to acceptance and/or rejection installment agreements. c. Identiﬁes and deﬁnes the next steps in the rejection process of install- ment agreements, Independent Administrative Review (IAR) and Collection Appeal Program. d. Deﬁnes the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) referral process. e. Provides information on installment agreement user fees. (

) Purpose - This chapter provides procedures for approval and monitoring of stallment agreements, including the level of approval authority necessary different types of agreements. It provides procedures for providing the taxpayers with an independent administrative review when a revenue plans to reject a request for installment agreement. This chapter provides policy and procedures for providing taxpayer’s appeal rights on rejected requests for agreements, defaulted agreements, and terminated installment agreements. (
) Audience - These procedures and guidance apply to IRS Field Collection Revenue Officers and Group Managers. (
) Policy Owner- Director, Collection Policy, is the policy owner of this IRM. (
) Program Owner- Collection Policy, Case Resolution Alternatives, is the program owner of this IRM. (
) Primary Stakeholders- The primary stakeholders affected or impacted this IRM are: • Field Collection • Independent Administrative Review • Insolvency • Appeals • Taxpayer Advocate Service (

) Program Goals- Installment Agreements can be a viable case resolution many delinquent accounts. By following the direction in this IRM section, employees can ensure installment agreements are approved when processed correctly, and that taxpayers will be granted the right to an dent review when the employee plans to reject an installment agreement. Employees also ensure that taxpayers receive appeal rights on all rejected requests for installment agreements. (

) This chapter will discuss the process and procedures for approval and ing of installment agreements. It provides procedures to provide taxpayers an independent administrative review when a revenue officer plans to request for installment agreement. This chapter provides policy and for providing appeal rights on rejected requests for installment agreements.
This IRM describes the installment agreement process. Speciﬁcally, IRM 5.14.9:
Field Collection Group Managers and Territory Managers are responsible ensuring the guidance and procedures described in this IRM are complied
with. (

) Program Reports: a. Monthly Installment Agreement Trend Report. Sourced from the tion Activity Report (CAR), Case Resolution Alternatives (CRA) and reviews a monthly Installment Agreement trend report that data on the various types of installment agreements and compares over year data on installment agreement inventory levels, the number installment agreements initiated, default rates, full pay rates and collected. Any anomalies are identiﬁed and researched for potential causes. Negative trends are identiﬁed and causes are addressed. (

) Program Reviews: a. Case reviews are conducted by Group Managers and NQRS to ensure compliance with this IRM. b. Operational reviews are conducted by Territory Managers and Area Director annually to evaluate program delivery and conformance to ad- ministrative and compliance requirements. (

) Independent Administrative Review, with few exceptions, is required of all rejected installment agreement proposals. In addition, all rejection, modiﬁca- tion, and termination decisions are subject to appeal procedures. (

) The Integrated Collection System (ICS) ensures that taxpayer conditions requirements for Streamlined or In-Business Express installment agreement processing criteria, that there are no unﬁled returns, and requires group manager approval for all non-streamlined installment agreements. (
) The Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) programming requires that all open modules be included in an installment agreement for input to be ful. (

) Frequently used terms in this IRM along with their deﬁnition: a. Delinquent taxes: balance due, ACS balance due accounts, and/or status accounts b. Accrued taxes: unassessed amounts due on returns, missed estimated tax payments or under-deposited Federal Tax Deposits (FTDs) as of date of contact c. Current taxes: Federal Tax Deposits (FTDs) and Estimated tax (ES) that become due after the date of contact Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
G

Any anomalies are identiﬁed and researched for potential causes. Negative trends are identiﬁed and causes are addressed.

) Group Managers must approve most installment agreements. Speciﬁcally, in- stallment agreements must be approved by managers when: a. the agreement is not a guaranteed or streamlined agreement; b. an in-business trust fund taxpayer is involved; c. the taxpayer is allowed to skip more than
payments in a

-month period (including systemic skip); d. there is an extension of the statutory period for collection, regardless of the length of the agreement or the amount of tax at issue; or e. partial payment installment agreements are involved in accordance with the procedures provided in IRM
, Partial Payment Installment Agreements and the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED). (

) Group Managers have the authority to approve all installment agreements, including partial payment installment agreements secured in connection with CSED extensions. There is no dollar limit set for group manager approval of installment agreements. (See IRM
, Notice of Federal Tax Lien and Installment Agreements, regarding no dollar limits and IRM
, Statute Expiration Date (CSED): Law, Policy and Procedures, on processing requirements with waivers.) (

) Submit installment agreements to managers for review and approval after all necessary case actions are taken, including thorough documentation of completed investigations and ﬁnancial analysis (see IRM
, Installment Agreement Acceptance and Rejection Determinations). Case histories must noted that installment agreements are pending and TC
AC
was unless the agreement will be immediately approved (i.e. a streamlined or Express IA). (See IRM

, Identifying Pending, Approved and Rejected Installment Agreement Proposals on IDRS). Inform taxpayers if approval of agreements is delayed. If managers do not approve installment agreements, refer to IRM
regarding Independent Administrative Review. (

) After investigation, analysis and necessary actions, immediately request gerial approval of installment agreements (or input of installment agreements for those cases that do not require managerial approval.) Installment agreement payments may not be accepted and posted as such unless ment agreements are approved. Do not monitor cases to ensure taxpayers

) The Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) is used to monitor most Install- ment agreements for timely payments on accounts, as well as to determine whether taxpayers remain in compliance with current ﬁling and paying ments. IDRS also monitors agreements based on the locator numbers recorded at the time agreements are input. (See IRM
, Securing Install- ment Agreements, Exhibit

) Accounts are considered routine installment agreements when the type of does not meet the criteria for any other type of IA (Guaranteed, Streamlined, Direct Debit, Manually Monitored Installment Agreement (MMIA), In Business Trust Fund (IBTF) or IBTF-Express). In order to close BMF accounts as routine, all employment tax ﬁling requirements must be closed. (

) The preferred method of closing a Routine IA is by choosing Option A on the ICS Installment Agreement menu. Choosing this method of closure allows IA to be systemically uploaded from ICS to IDRS (Status

) Certain assessments and agreements are not compatible with IDRS ing. The types of agreements listed below must be manually monitored in Centralized Case Processing to ensure compliance with the terms of agree- ments: a. NMF assessments in either notice or Bal Due status; b. agreements calling for variable or percentage amounts; c. agreements with irregular payment intervals; d. BMF agreements secured from two or more parties at different on the same liability (partnerships, multiple entities, etc.) e. L Freeze modules during pending Joint and Several Liability Relief IRC
claims; f. Restitution Based Assessments; g. any other agreement not compatible with IDRS monitoring. (

is not input on manually monitored installment agreements. The modules will remain open on ICS and will be transferred to Centralized Processing for monitoring. (

(e) and the taxpayer’s right to challenge the IRS’s decision and be heard, taxpayers are entitled to an independent administrative review of proposed terminations of installment agreements or rejections of proposed installment agreement requests.
a. The employee will provide a response that is accurate and communi

cated in a clear, concise, professional, and easy to understand manner when communicating the determination. Contact employees (including revenue officers) and managers must ensure that all actions relative to this independent administrative review are documented in case including:

the date the case is sent to the Independent Administrative Reviewer (IAR); the date the case is received from the Independent Administrative Reviewer (IAR); and the date the case is forwarded for second level review (if applicable).

, Compliance and Installment Agreements.) When planning to reject a request for an installment agreement: a. Notify taxpayers that rejection of the request is being recommended if that is the next planned action, but do not notify taxpayers of actual rejection of the installment agreement request until after independent ministrative review. b. Managers must review and concur with plans to reject installment agreement requests prior to independent administrative review. Note: This is accomplished by signing Form
, Request for Install- ment Agreement - Independent Review Prior to Rejection, (see

)(e)) making a notation in the case history on the Inte- grated Collection System, if available. c. If managers request additional information or action, these should be requested of the taxpayer or secured from the appropriate source, without commenting to the taxpayer regarding approval status of the agreement other than that the request is being considered. Also, set deadlines in accordance with the procedures provided in IRM

, Setting Deadlines and Receiving Payments, if appropriate. d. In addition to exercising care with regard to conveying rejection of requests, exercise care regarding conveying acceptances. Speciﬁcally, though the plan to accept an installment agreement request can be shared, do not convey acceptance if a request requires managerial approval until approval is obtained. If rejection is the next planned action, the following information should be provided to the Independent Administrative Reviewer (IAR). For current case routing instructions see http://mysbse.web.irs.gov/collection/ceaso/contacts/
aspx a. Form

, Request for Installment Agreement - Independent Review Prior to Rejection; b. a statement regarding the reason(s) for the proposed rejection. Bear in mind that the basis for the rejection of an installment agreement could be the subject of an immediate appeal or a future Collection Due Process hearing; c. IDRS printouts associated with the case ﬁle, including IDRS CC (See IRM
regarding approvals); d. any documentation submitted by the taxpayer in connection with the in- stallment agreement request; e. Form

, Request for Installment Agreement - Independent Review Prior to Rejection, must be signed by the employee responsible for the rejection determination and the employee’s manager; and f. Record on Form
, Request for Installment Agreement - Review Prior to Rejection, the date it was forwarded for independent ministrative review.

reversed with a TC 972 AC 043, using the same date of the originating transaction code. (See IRM 5.14.1.3, Identifying Pending, Approved and Rejected Installment Agreement Proposals on IDRS and IRM 5.14.1.4.2, Compliance and Installment Agreements.)

If managers request additional information or action, these should be requested of the taxpayer or secured from the appropriate source, without commenting to the taxpayer regarding approval status of the agreement other than that the request is being considered. Also, set deadlines in accordance with the procedures provided in IRM

, Setting Deadlines and Receiving Payments, if appropriate. In addition to exercising care with regard to conveying rejection of requests, exercise care regarding conveying acceptances. Speciﬁcally, though the plan to accept an installment agreement request can be shared, do not convey acceptance if a request requires managerial approval until approval is obtained.
a. Form

, Request for Installment Agreement - Independent Review Prior to Rejection; b. a statement regarding the reason(s) for the proposed rejection. IDRS printouts associated with the case ﬁle, including IDRS CC (See IRM
regarding approvals); d. any documentation submitted by the taxpayer in connection with the stallment agreement request; e. Form

Note: Installment agreements are not considered “pending” if taxpayers are not in compliance with ﬁling requirements at the time of their request and therefore
5.14 Installment Agreements

do not require independent administrative review. If the taxpayer’s in- agreement request was identiﬁed as “pending” in error, advise the they do not have a pending installment agreement due to lack of with ﬁling requirements at the time of the request. Ensure all that contain a pending installment agreement indicator (TC 971 AC are reversed with a TC 972 AC 043, using the same date of the origi- transaction code. (See IRM 5.14.1.3, Identifying Pending, Approved Rejected Installment Agreement Proposals on IDRS and IRM and Installment Agreements.)
) The Independent Administrative Reviewer (IAR) will add the case to ICS no later than ﬁve business days after receipt. (

) The Independent Administrative Reviewer (IAR) reviews the decision to reject installment agreement requests independent of employees’ and managers’ opinions. The IAR must exercise independent judgment to determine if rejection of the installment agreement request is appropriate. The IAR should use problem solving and negotiation techniques and consider the taxpayer’s perspective when working toward case resolution. (

) In deciding to uphold or overturn a proposed rejection, the Independent istrative Reviewer (IAR) should: a. Consider the case as a whole; b. Focus on the reasons for the proposed rejection given by the contact employee (or, if appropriate, the reasons for the proposed rejection by the group manager); c. Determine whether the proposed installment agreement would fully pay the liability before the CSED (see IRM

, Partial Payment Install- ment Agreements and the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED) for exceptions). Use IDRS CC ICOMP or other source to support the decision to reject an installment agreement request for this reason; d. Review the analysis of the taxpayer’s ﬁnancial condition to determine whether the payment amount requested by the taxpayer is adequate given the taxpayer’s ability to pay; e. Determine whether the taxpayer is in compliance with all ﬁling require- ments (see IRM

, Compliance and Installment Agreements); f. Determine whether positions expressed by the taxpayer were considered in the interview or review process; and g. Determine if reasons for rejection provided by the revenue officer or his/ her manager should be provided to the taxpayer. Considering that the basis for the rejection can be the subject of an immediate appeal or a future Collection Due Process hearing, there should be very few circum- stances when the taxpayer should not be told of the reasons for rejection. The Independent Administrative Reviewer (IAR) should ensure that the reasons for rejection are well documented in the ﬁle including, necessary, why a partial payment installment agreement was not appro- priate. (
) The Independent Administrative Reviewer (IAR) may: a. Recommend that taxpayers be granted installment agreements (of the same amount proposed by taxpayers, or a different amount);

The IAR use problem solving and negotiation techniques and consider the taxpayer’s perspective when working toward case resolution.

ment ( IAR Advisory Territory Manager) for a decision.

) Taxpayers have the right to receive assistance from the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) if they experience difficultly in resolving their problems with IRS. Refer taxpayers to TAS when contact meets TAS criteria, (see IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria) or when you are unable to resolve the taxpayer’s issues the same day. The deﬁnition of day” is within
hours. “Same day” cases include cases you can resolve in

hours, as well as cases in which you have taken steps within hours to begin resolving the taxpayer’s issue. Do not refer same day cases TAS unless the taxpayer asks to be transferred to TAS and the case meets TAS criteria. Refer to IRM
, Same-Day Resolution by Operations. (

The Act amended IRC
to provide certain limitations to install- ment agreement user fees. The Act’s amendments to IRC
apply to installment agreements entered into on or after April
• User fees for IAs may not exceed the amount of such fee as in

• Installment agreement user fees will be waived for low-income taxpayers who agree to make electronic payments through a debit strument. Taxpayers are low income, for IA user fee purposes, if adjusted gross income for the most recent year is at or below

Installment agreement user fees will be waived for low-income taxpayers who agree to make electronic payments through a debit in- strument. Taxpayers are low income, for IA user fee purposes, if their adjusted gross income for the most recent year is at or below
% of the federal poverty guidelines.
Note: Programming has been input to systemically waive the user fee on a DDIA when the taxpayer meets the low-income threshold.
5.14 Installment Agreements
Installment agreement user fees will be reimbursed to low-income taxpayers that are unable to make electronic payments through a debit instrument upon completion of the installment agreement.
Note: It is anticipated that programming to systemically reimburse the user fee for eligible taxpayers will be available in January 2019.
The customer can also ﬁle a Form
, Application for Reduced User Fee for Installment Agreements:
• For IAs entered into before April
, if the customer’s income has decreased signiﬁcantly and has provided an explanation (i.e. ployed, etc.), in any form (correspondence, CIS etc.) and their income falls at or below
percent of the Federal Health & Human Services Guidelines (FHHSG), we can allow a reduced user fee for IAs. • For IAs entered into on or after April
, if a taxpayer has an adjusted gross income, as reported on their most recently ﬁled tax return, that is at or below
% of the FHHSG, the user fee will be reduced and possibly waived or reimbursed if certain conditions apply. See Note below.
For IAs entered into on or after April

, there is a waiver of user fees for low-income taxpayers that agree to make electronic payments through a debit instrument (DDIA). If the low-income taxpayer indicates that she or he is unable to make electronic payments through a debit instrument, then the taxpayer will receive a reimbursement of the reduced user fee upon completion of the IA. The low-income taxpayer will not receive a reimburse- ment of the reduced user fee if the IA is terminated.
Completed Form 13844, Application for Reduced User Fee for Installment Agreements, should be sent to:
